translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽. The Chapter with Yasas
The Elder Gayākassapa’s Birth Story
I had a robe of antelope hide,
and I was carrying a load of firewood;
after I had carried the firewood,🔽I brought the milk-rice to the hermitage.
At that time, the Fortunate One,
the Victor, who was alone, without a companion,
came to my hermitage,
shining at all times.
After I had gladdened my own mind,🔽and after worshipping the Fortunate One,
I raised up the milk-rice with both hands,
and gave it to the Buddha.
In the past, thirty-one aeons ago,
the fruit that I gave then;
I do not know of a bad destination,
this is the fruit of giving the milk-rice.
My defilements have been burned up,
… and so on …
I live undefiled.
How welcome it was for me,
… and so on …
the Fortunate One’s instruction has been done.
The four analytical insights,
… and so on …
the Fortunate One’s instruction has been done.”🔽Thus the venerable Elder Gayākassapa recited these verses.

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā gayākassapo thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.🔽Gayākassapattherassāpadānaṁ tatiyaṁ.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā gayākassapaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati 🔽gayākassapa therassa apadānam
translated: The Elder Gayākassapa’s Birth Story, the third.
